answers.text: @madhuvjk at least these people are doing SOMETHING for the migrant workers other than spreading hate speech abt the govt

@policentifff apologise for everything? maybe apologise for something first? and who do you think has the responsibility and power to manage these ‘employers in private sectors’, or is MOM just there for fun? They are a regulatory authority and in the event of a crisis they have to mobilise a collective response, not wait for individual employer to go settle and put the workers and country at risk. Doesn’t take a PhD or masters to know this. Criticising decisions and responses doesn’t mean a lack of respect for our government, rather holding them accountable, it’s not an authoritarian regime bruh

@madhuvjk she is your minister, & if u not happy pls go take masters or phD & try get urself elected as the next minister of manpower. u dont even know what kind of stress shes undergoing rn, is the government supposed to apologise for EVERYTHING & be blamed for EVERYTHING? the employers in the private sectors shld b blamed & SHLD apologise & take actions. show some respect for our governing body, if not dont use edusave/medisave/any benefit started by PAP

@madhuvjk by the way, i didnt want to say this but please, do some research if u have the guts to be flaunting this statement “who do you think has the responsibility and power blabla” you clearly have not educated yourself & do any form of ground research. Majority of these foreign workers sign a contract clause asking them to settle any disputes w the employers before going to MOM, without a COMPLAINT mom has no jurisdiction to step in & interfere. AND do u think these workers want to risk their rice bowl by complaining? no. theyre employers terrorize them & threaten them not to because there will be consequences. in this case its clear that the jurisdiction is no longer w MOM, rather its w the employers who purposely engage in mistreatment & unfair practices.

text:
Foreign workers are more important than Singaporean?
First class government?
Untill today I didn't hear any government say sorry to our nation,👎

Here’s a take: what if the question was crafted with malicious intent. If one is to answer YES - it might come across “weak”. If one answers NO - it will come across heartless. An inquiry that is possibly designed to trap for future ammunition... however, I personally believe that the minister handled the question rather elegantly. She chose to focus on the positive/grateful sentiments of the foreign workers. Establishing the idea that there is Low tension between the two bodies of government and foreign workforce. Well done! ✨✨✨
In her world, if she bumps into you and makes u fall, she will only say sorry if u demand for it. 👏👏

TBH the FW will be worst off in their own country now...or working in any other countries. Our government has done a VERY GOOD JOB looking after them, giving food, accommodations and healthcare.  Pls read the news to know what’s going on around the world and you will realize that they are a lot better off here than anywhere else in the world. Appreciate what our government has done in this crisis for us and the FW. If we don’t support our government and our own country who will? It’s always easy to criticize and point fingers till you have to do the job, you will know how tough it is. I hope all Singaporean stay united to fight through this pandemic. Stay positive not negative! 💪🏻💪🏻💪🏻
🇸🇬Keep it up !💞Amitabha 💐🙏🏻
Damage done, hush and apologised

I agree that the gov is doing a good job handling the FWs. But I find that it was a little too late for the gov to finally look into the FWs. SG was praised by many on how it handled the covid situation in the early stages but that was during the time where the gov wasn't looking into FWs as much as they do now. It was as though they were neglected. So an apology? Probably not. But admitting a mistake and wanting to improve is what makes a good country.
So many ppl with high morale commenting here, chill guys. Just be nice to them and show them the humanity they deserve when you see them after this. Peace.

before pointing fingers at the government and blaming them, have we as individuals ever done anything within our means to help the migrant workers even before COVID19? We've all chosen to be ignorant and how many of us can say that we've ever thought of helping them? I've ever had a migrant worker make way for me to enter a lift he has been waiting for even before I came, saying because I'm Singaporean, and I think it's our actions as Singaporeans, as individuals that causes them to think that they're not on the same level as us, things like this are not caused by the government's nonchalance or inability to govern our country, these are things caused by our actions as Singaporeans.

text: The more appropriate question to ask is what has the govt done with the FW levy they collected monthly, (conservative estimated at $500 x 500,000 FWs = $250,000,000 per mth) which they justify to control influx of FWs and take care of social and infrastructural needs to accommodate them. This cost is ultimately passed to consumers. Obviously they have not done much, resulting in current situation, Now after waiving 2 mths of FW levy collection, they suddenly became "protector of FWs", at the expense of their employers and tax payers... some accountability from govt to all Singaporeans will be helpful to prevent the same from recurring. Stop ownself check ownself!

text: oh no this comment section
for some reason the way she speaks sounds satisfying

It’s so tough being a leader. During peace time, people who blames them don’t even raise such issues, fight for them, help them. Don’t just point fingers at such testing time, its easy to do that and it’s not needed. How about we just work together and provide solutions? Don’t be critical, be constructive.

answers.text: @samuelchinmx appreciate it. But on the handling of the virus situation, think about it this way... We have 100 MPs including ministers for such a small country. That's more than 1MP per square km of land and they are paid the best salaries in the world. Should we accept poor or average results?  Why tell us that we prepared since SARS? They have the resources and intelligence of the country to tackle the problem with foresight and not issue reactive measures. But instead they made fancy videos early on showing how they contained the virus etc... Why try to milk everything to their favour? Why stop fw from being sent to hospitals for testing in Feb?  Many questions are left unanswered, can't blame the sharp thinkers from feeling frustrated right

@sinkietemplatelife Love this conversation bro. I feel that because sg heavily relies on foreign investors and economy for sustainability. The salary does limit  the corruption because of how small we are. It’s like “I’m so rich, I don’t need anything else” vs “I’m paid lesser than a CEO but I have so much power so why not I...” It won’t work in other big countries because they have natural resources. So then the qn of “why can’t we have MPs that have good heart?” I would love it. But for now, if can eliminate money as a factor for corruption, I would. 
We won’t know the limitations of their resources. Real numbers will scare the public. The govt is trying to assure us. It’s more than just physical battle, it’s also psychological. I think in Feb it was pretty early? Like mostly contained, no research of asymptomatic, no FW case (or was it 1?). Too much of everything will breakdown the systems - healthcare etc. At least they were prepared for army camps, expos, offshore stays, chalets etc. I think it’s really commendable compared to other countries already. Their immediate lockdown just “killed” everyone. It’s effective to a certain extent. But our economy will really suffer. So many businesses are bankrupt (not reported in news). So I guess that’s why they chose to do it in layers.

@sinkietemplatelife You are right. I apologise that I might have misled your thoughts. I’m referring to the attitude and heart behind the people who probed. The doctors and watch groups did recommend, but I dunno if the NMPs did extensively (gotta research). PM Lee did explain why there was a u-turn in mask wearing: WHO’s stand, asymptotic discovery etc. Moreover sg doesn’t have mask wearing culture like HK. And the influx of measures will induce fear into people, which is way scarier than the virus. We saw hoarding in supermarkets already earlier this season. This virus is new, and doctors are finding out new things everyday. Sg govt had to make a decision swiftly. It’s easier said than done. Many of us can’t even decide in a group what to eat. We have limited testing kits daily too. My friends were rejected when they volunteer to be tested. For all you know, we might all be carriers. And the govt chose to care and give to the FWs instead,  who majority are healthy!

Regarding the apology, I felt it should be voluntary and comes from the heart. No point having an insincere one. Maybe the NMP felt injustice towards FW, maybe the MP felt the NMP just wanna exercise power etc. Communication needs to be clarified here between them both. So if the direct party (FWs) demanded an apology, I’m sure the govt might give. So again, it’s a 3rd party (NMP) asking, and the MP might feel NMP has a wrong intention. Idk. 
For the govt, they are helping as many ways as they can already and that’s their way of showing love (acts of svc). For the NMP it might be words. The way we are governed made us very practical growing up. Govt give money, we say not enough. We sing songs, people say we hypocrite. People can never be fully pleased.

So I do agree with what you said. And I appreciate it. The govt had to make a decision, between WHO or doctors/watch groups. It’s not easy.

@samuelchinmx sorry this is not factually right. There have been many warnings given from the migrant workers watch group as well as recommendations by doctors to wear masks early. Aren't all these constructive recommendations?

@samuelchinmx the high salary justification no logic also. It takes a willingness to serve to be a civil servant. The mark to market salary etc is also not accurate as when they screw up, they don't get fired or demoted like in the private sector. Greed knows no bounds, high salary does not prevent a person of poor character from wanting more.  When choose a surgeon, do you want someone who became a doctor out of passion, or do you want someone who became a doctor because it paid well?

text: Ehh suddenly the keyboard warriors fly back liao

In all fairness, FW staying in the dorms have a part to play in keeping their own living space hygienic. It doesn't matter that much how big your living space is, if you live messy, the place is going to be messy. A family of 5 living in a bungalow can pile up thrash and rubbish as well. In the military, you only got 1 cupboard and a bed but can keep your space squecky clean as well. So everyone got a part to play. In tekong, every soldier in BMT also stay double deck beds and some bunks also very small. Never see before, go see Ah Boys to Men 1.

answers.text: @dekohlourised learn to have some manners. Your mum never teach you manners? 👏👏👏👏

@tcheeyong91 how is keeping your space hygienic going to matter if someone sharing that space has COVID-19? You scrub the place down with dettol every day also no use if that one infected person lives with other uninfected people? Stop this prejudiced narrative of “they should have kept themselves cleaner”
@dekohlourised shame on you for calling racist on everything. We are talking about hygiene here.
@dekohlourised gtfo
@tcheeyong91 stop being such an entitled boy

@tcheeyong91 finally, someone who understands. Our migrant workers have to treat their dormitories like home and keep them clean too. Nobody has the right to barge in and tell them constantly how to do that right? In terms of safe distancing, how have companies educated their workers? Also what personal precautionary measures did the workers take? Did they go to crowded places and risk infection too besides their dorms. Don’t dump the responsibility squarely on the govt and all Singaporeans. Seriously, can we go in and invade their dorms asking to check at will? No right? What right do we have? Employers should be the ones to take care of their welfare. Everyone, including our migrant worker friends has a part to play. Most of us do appreciate the contributions of our migrant friends. Hopefully, we can learn from this episode.

@dekohlourised you literally only need a bed and a locker if you are here to work. Thats the same as an army bunk as a recruit. Only a bed and a locker. Everyone wants hygiene, you just have to work for it. Squeeze 10 Japanese housewives into a room to stay and see whether the room will be messy. It will be absolutely clean and tidy. All because of culture. I am saying all the fault lies on the FW, it is afterall the culture. Perhaps after this incident, they will have discipline to maintain their hygiene.
@tcheeyong91 exactly!
@tcheeyong91 educate yourself bro- there were cases in NS swept under the carpet, and the government PAUSED NS- these men went home- early intervention prevented an outbreak in BUNKS.

@tcheeyong91 hi chee yong stop living under a rock and take a look at some of the dorms. In camps, the living space per person IS more than that in dorms. There is sufficient facilities for all (toilets, eating area)- that is not the case of dorms. How does one maintain basic hygiene when he is housed in a sub-par facility, crammed into a ROOM with dozens other? Would u insinuate that migrants don’t WANT basic hygiene?
@dekohlourised you are obviously just trying to pretend you have the moral highground here instead of understanding the issue. Hypocrite.

@niiiiizarrrrr don't waste time arguing with people who cannot see the bigger picture. In army it's tightly controlled, as they say it's army. No use fighting with someone who only think himself. This guy first one to paotoh his teammates, confirm
@tcheeyong91 lmao when you can't argue so keep deflecting

@tcheeyong91 it’s not even high ground it’s BASIC decency mind you- stop saying u understand the issue with your bleak picture of comparison between NS and FW dorms. The workers don’t even have lockers- lack alone sufficient space for privacy. Can u READ before u speak before being an empty vessel? In parliament, former MOM chief Tan Chuan Jin has already warned, based on scientific facts, that there will be an outbreak in dormitories as it is SEVERELY LACKING IN SPACE and basic amenities to help workers keep hygiene.
@madhuvjk thousands of soldiers share bunks with other soldiers but we don't see an army camp outbreak. Hmmm so is it a coincidence? You have to ask yourself.

@tcheeyong91 look at my comments- facts and logic, why are u bringing in manners now? So now that you’ve come to a realisation that your argument has no basis, u have to resort to personal Attack? Wow what a great representation of millennials

text: Perhaps I may be the only one feeling this way but I feel like this needs to be said. I did not gave a hoot about the migrate workers and I don’t give a hoot now. How they lived, ate, mingled I didn’t care unless they troubled me which none of them did. Now I can sympathise that they are going through troubled times and have a lot more at stake now but I have given my fair share of donations and I have washed my hands of them. The Govt can put in whatever measures they would like as Long as its in the interest of protecting them and the community as a whole. Because quite frankly I didn’t give a hoot about them before covid, don’t really give a hoot now, and I know I won’t be giving much hoot later. Apologise, don’t apologise, don’t really think it matters n don’t really care; just make sure they’re fed and their families are fed 🤷🏻‍♀️

answers.text: @omgits_her_  you and your ‘hoots’ 😂

text: You have done your best. Nobody is right or wrong. We just have to pull together through this tough times together. 🙏😢

I don't think saying sorry or apologising should be made into such a big deal. sure our migrant workers may not have had good treatment prior to this crisis. But I think it's of greater value when we see our government acting by ensuring that they are all now getting tested, getting treatment, basic care needs like food and safe accommodation and a promise that they'll continue to be better taken care of. Before trying to corner our ministers and extorting an apology, look at our northern neighbours and how they're foreign workers are faring.

answers.text: @taehyung_0ppp4 this is so well said. I cannot agree more with your comment. 👍🏻

text: Lol the government isn’t responsible for their living  conditions. Their EMPLOYERS are. They are the ones who should be apologising to the foreign workers. Get your facts right before y’all start jumping on the government. Do you seriously expect the government to preoccupy themselves with EVERY foreign worker’s living conditions as well as our own citizens???

answers.text: @smoldumbnut you literally state one line on "Yes the government could do better to ensure that" and then spent the rest of the paragraph trying to shame any individual (keyword: individual, a single person with extremely limited resources to contribute and not the most powerful congregation of policy makers in our country) who do not go out of their way to help these people? You are trying to shift the blame to a single person's efforts or lack there of
@smoldumbnut come I clap for you... 👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼

@smoldumbnut "do you seriously expect the government to preoccupy themselves with EVERY foreign worker's living conditions as well as our own citizen" This statement stinks of privilege. Yes? I expect my government to ensure that the companies they contract out to do not keep their labourers in an inhospitable environment? This are not Malaysian foreign workers building a new drain in KL or Indonesian foreign workers paving a road in Jakarta. These are people who are by proxy of an construction agency, living and working for the needs of Singaporeans. They live on our land, they work on our streets, they spend their salary on food and amenities bought in our country, the only thing that distinguishes these people from our labourers is a pink coloured identification card. To excuse the mistreatment of people who live and work in the name of our country on the basis of a classification you are born into is indicative of an ungrateful society that prides itself on the exclusivity of having birth coordinates located on these 721km^2 of land. A number that is a human construct being used to justify an inhumane predisposition of people that were not fortunate enough to be graced with an upbringing on this island yet have worked twice as hard to earn their place here is disgusting and disgraceful. For all the civics and morals lessons spent on the youth throughout their years in school to be wasted on the inability to value basic human empathy over a few pocketed dollars you never see in the end.

@smoldumbnut Yes, I can say I have done more than my part to contribute to the migrant worker society in Singapore. Then what? The whataboutism and deflection ends there? I visit their dormitories and help serve them Briyani then that's it full-stop? The discussion ends if I didn't lias on behalf of my mosque volunteer committee to help some of them obtain prepaid cards for their phones? Were I not to have done a single one of the aforementioned charitable acts my criticism would not be valid? I find that one of the most stupid strawmen arguments being flailed around this comment section. Am I one to assert my kindness because I have helped them in the past? No. But does that mean that the criticism of anyone else who have not gone to my efforts is invalid? Of course not. Even a thought their way is more helpful then people trying to shield the most powerful entity on this island from any openings for remorse in the management of our labourers. For someone so "appreciative" of their efforts you seem to be content enough with their current predicament to excuse that because the government says employers are "expected" to provide them with adequate conditions, that is enough to ensure that they do? Because employers are "expected" to do so, suddenly their living areas all clean and not oversaturated with people? What if employers fail their "expectations"? The authorities can just dust their hands and say "well that's that I tried! Whatever happens agter that is not my concern!"

@yangzhi1989 I think you need to reread my comment properly. I have never mentioned that employers send their workers to dormitories because it’s cheap. According to MOM’s website it is the responsibility of employers to Ensure that the foreign workers live in proper working conditions (https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-worker/housing). Which means, even in dormitories or housing estates, they are to enforce proper living standards (eg no exceeding of limit of FW per unit - https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-worker/housing/various-types-of-housing ) I don’t know why you’re coming in talking about cheap housing when literally no one is talking about the expenses of housing them or even hiring them? Before you come jumping in and saying how ill informed I am, do me a favour and read properly and get your facts right.

@hisguiltycrown no one is saying we shouldn’t care about them? In fact I’m rather appreciative towards them and their efforts for what they’ve contributed to Singapore. But there’s a reason why MOM guidelines are in place (if you’re not clear, please read on them). Employers are EXPECTED to uphold the integrity of them and to ensure adequate living and working conditions. Yes, the government (and everyone) could do better to Ensure that, but did you really care about this community before all these? Can you actively say that YOU have done your part to ensure they never faced all these discrimination and lack of proper care? If you have, then thank you, we do need more people like you. That being said, since you’re apparently very passionate about each and every foreign workers living conditions, i suggest you seek an employment along this line or continue to proactively aid our foreign workers so your words aren’t just empty bull. Thank you :-)
@smoldumbnut then they have to come check everyone’s house to see how they set up bedroom for domestic helpers too.

@hisguiltycrown instead of the pooling of our 3.47 million citizens' belief and resources? Who have the ability to make a nation encompassing impact instead of individual charity? You spent one line acknowledging the government's (the most powerful body in our society)  faults and the rest of the paragraph questioning why each individual hasn't done more as if the government does not represent the beliefs and decisions of said each individual combined and are funded by the time and effort of once again, said each and every single individual constituting the Singaporean republic?

@hisguiltycrown I have not stated that I am content with their current predicament, and I do feel that things can definitely improve.  If employers fail their expectations, then it is expected that the relevant authorities do something about it and report to the higher ups whenever necessary, and would be better if they proceeded with follow ups to ensure that standards are being enforced. Since you brought up that point, do you have any other suggestion as to how to avoid future problems from arising? Because I think we can really use them. I brought up the point of asking if you have done something meaningful for the migrant workers in the past because, as you can see, there are plentiful of keyboard warriors ready to point fingers and blame the government when they never cared about our FW and are just jumping on the bandwagon simply for the fun of it. Constructive criticism is obviously appreciated, but when it becomes unnecessary noice and negative comments with no help whatsoever, is it really needed? If the same trolls actually put in the same amount of effort to bring attention to these FW’s plight from the beginning, would their situation be as bad as it is? My point of my original comment wasn’t to shame the government or any individual. It was to be the voice of reason to people who were demanding unreasonable and unfeasible actions. At the end of the day, we want the best for our foreign workers, I just don’t see a need for people to solely shame and blame the government for their current situation.

@smoldumbnut stop blaming employers when you aren’t one who hires foreign workers. There are regulations which restricts where foreign workers can live. Do you really believe that employers send their workers to dormitories because it’s cheap?Bed spaces at dormitories aren’t cheap. Your comment really just shows how ill-informed you are.

text: But when this happen .. Singapore did best .,
No .. they have lived in fare conditions
The answer does not match the question. period.

answers.text: @jackson.chongts her answer was No, because the government is spending their efforts on helping them instead of only apologising for something they are not responsible for.

text: Very diff to hear this government apologise and just say more could have been done. IF acted sooner collectively for everyone on this island. IF measures were taken sooner. IF something even a small thing could have been done that could have altered the infection to spread rampantly among the migrant workers. I thought we were taught saying sorry isn't weak.. Its a strong virtue. Just shows a leader who has compassion and heart for its people.

answers.text: @raizj_2006 you don't need to be a soldier to be instilled with discipline. You ever work or are you a kid?

@heiciel by what you just said, you basically endorsed the point that their dorm hygiene is not maintained well by themselves. Not because its impossible, its just difficult. And its understandable because a bunch of guys staying together would be messy without a leader to control them. The FW are adults, they suffer the consequences of their hygiene. Thats all.

@shidahhashim yes! Sg government has done many good things, but they never apologize for the mistakes they have a done. A strong government doesn't have to perfect, but willing to improve. Singaporeans have to learn not to be so prideful that we cannot apologize to the people helping us build our country.

@tcheeyong91 Lmao. Tougher doesn't mean they can be put through such harsh living conditions. Idk if you understand this but they don't come from countries where emphasis is placed on hygiene AND putting many workers in 1 dorm will worsen the conditions even if they put in effort which I'm sure they maintain personal hygiene but sometimes environmental hygiene is not something we can control. What if there's ants infestation because of the dorm location? Huh? Then what? You want them to buy chemicals to clean ? These are people who work long shifts to send money back home, not pampered children who take things for granted. Shame on you. Our government should have implemented laws so that companies ensure the safety of their workers instead of deflecting and edgy kids like you should really put yourself in other people's shoes.
@raizj_2006 👏👏👏 your comment is even better. Congrats.
@tcheeyong91 what a dumb comment
@wayerdo omg! so well-written! kudos to you keyboard warrior 6782728!

@heiciel sorry but the truth is that you have to clean your own living space even if your professional job is tiring. It is a dorm and not a hotel. Nobody paid for bedmaking service. And I believe these workers are tougher than you. They can do it. They just need a little reminder and push. You don't use your brain a lot right? You mean hardwork outside the house entitles you to not clean your house? You been having your mama clean your house for you?
@tcheeyong91 lmao did I say they can't clean their homes? I'm saying that hygiene within DORMS are not that easily maintained BECAUSE TOO MANY PEOPLE ARE IN ONE ROOM. Can you not read?

@tcheeyong91 sorry but they are crammed into small dorms and you expect them to mop vacuum clean everyday as if they're not doing hard labour under the SG sun? Smells like a dumb privileged singaporean to me.
@heiciel your last sentence is describing yourself. Your idea that someone who works hard at work cannot clean their house when they reach home shows that you are the DUMB PRIVILEGED SINGAPOREAN.

@tcheeyong91 since you like to mention how FWs should clean up after themselves, you can go check the images of the dorms uploaded. Most of rooms are so crammed the workers have to hang their cloths on parts of the bed. There's barely a walkway left for them, cleaning takes a huge effort as they'd have to take turns shifting out their stuff. There are also photos were walls had MOULD. Which is caused by humidity and bad air flow which is attributed to the way the dorms are built. Foreign workers can't control that. Nor do they have the extra money needed to clean it. So are you going to blame this on them too?

@heiciel took the words right out of my mouth. Covid 19 is so contagious yet he thinks merely keeping the rooms with 9 other men tidy and clean will not spread it and they only have themselves to blame. Clusters was formed in churches, those people merely went there for a few hours of service in clean churches and yet they caught it. Let alone thousands of them living in clusters. Let's not kid ourselves that their living condition is somehow acceptable or that the government had no clue about it.  Once singaporeans disagree with the gov, we will get told to not just be all talk but do something. Do what? tell the gov their wrong and get fined or jailed thereafter? Plus I'm not being paid a 6 figures salary or more annually to do their job. FYI disagreeing with your government on certain areas is totally find!
@tcheeyong91 No u.
@tcheeyong91 Of course.At least i don't ask the workers to be trained like soldiers
@tcheeyong91 u also not there how u know they never clean? Then can ask them step up a bit and put little effort to make it tidy where's the link with training them up as soldier u stupiak?

@wayerdo the FW played a part in their hygiene too and they know it. Nobody force you to live in a messy dorm. You and your dormmates are ultimately in charge whether to organise things neatly and keep hygiene in check. So all parties at fault. The government fault is perhaps not playing a stricter supreme hygiene officer to go all dorms and control their room's housekeeping. Maybe you want suggest dorm operators conduct standby bed for all FW in dorms in future? Train them like soldiers.

@tcheeyong91 also, the virus spreads quick when people are in clusters. That doesn't have much to do w hygiene either. Our government allowed these companies to cram so many people in a room. Even if just 1 gets infected everyone will too. No matter how clean the room is. Hence Singapore should apologise because we did not implement harsher laws to ensure a safe living environment for these workers who are paid MUCH lesser for cheap labor and help build our country.
fine*

text: The real people that should be apologising to not only the foreign workers, but also Singaporeans, is the companies themselves. Ignoring the fact that they hire foreigners for cheap labour, they do not treat them as human. They are forced to live in terrible conditions. We, as taxpayers should not be paying for something the companies shouldve maintained from the start; proper living conditions of the foreign workers. It doesn't matter if we contribute $1 or $10,000 as taxpayers. As long as we contribute, we are taxpayers. All of us have the right to voice our opinions on the use of our money. We should get the companies to apologise to SINGAPOREANS, THE GOVERNMENT, AND THE FOREIGN WORKERS.

answers.text: @saus.ed 👍👏
@saus.ed should impose a fine to these companies who provided bad condition dormitories to the workers !

@estherhaha you are absolutely right 👍 hiring foreign workers ain't cheap. The levy imposed on the employers are pretty expensive and these levy are to discourage companies from hiring foreign workers and hire locals. The govt plays the ball game very well, just like a matrix. It leads to a point where there's no clear and win win solution for everyone. So in terms of not providing proper living conditions for the foreign workers, I can't blame the employers fully. The levy expensive already and still need to pay for a better living condition? It's a deep hole in the pocket

@saus.ed erm for sake of fairness, hygiene of the living quarters of the FW needs to be maintained by the FW themselves. text: Again, she deflected

answers.text: @dekohlourised what did they do wrong ffs? Their dorm room cleanliness is solely dependent on workers themselves, and years ago gov forced employers to put their workers in proper dorms, otherwise these workers could still be slping at work sites or offices with no proper facilities. Understand how it works instead of pointing fingers demanding fucking apologies

@dekohlourised Yeap, "get your facts CHECKED and dont be an empty vessel" to yourself. If you have to be ignorant to really HOW IT WORKS and to push everything to the gov then i dont see any point of arguing with you further because it's just pure prejudice. Still dont see the need for apologies.
@shuoke ok boomer

@shuoke your comment reeks of blatant ignorance. The problem is twofold, stemming from systemic negligence on both the government’s part as well as the dorm operator’s part. Cleanliness and hygiene is not solely dependent on workers themselves, but rather the facilities, amenities, time available. The limited space per person, toilet ratio, is bound to catalyse the spread of outbreak- if u can’t understand this concept, u can check it on WHO / or 2015 parliament speech by former MOM chief Tan Chuan Jin. The issue has been recognised by parliament, yet nothing Has been done, not even an Apology? If u can’t convince others by facts, u don’t have to stoop so Low and resort to vulgarities. At least be civic minded and not be such a terrible influence to your kid(hope u don’t). Forcing employers to get a shelter for the workers is BASIC decency- all around first world country, this is the most decent act to be done. However, it is done to a SUB PAR standard, why are u condoning the government’s negligence? Do u think the migrant workers don’t deserve at least a sufficient space with amenities? Are u saying, u understand “how it works” which means long term negligence and profiting off the workers through a capitalist structure- and u have the audacity to claim the moral high ground? Get your facts CHECKED and don’t be an empty vessel

@soojieling she didnt. Her answer is a clear no because an apology is unnecessary. Our government is spending our resources on other more meaningful actions for migrant workers. Singaporeans treat "sorry" and "thank you" too seriously. Action speaks louder than words.
@shuoke my uncle takes on projects from the gov

@deaan An apology reflects that they acknowledge their mistake- which is KEY. Are u saying that they did nothing wrong on their part? To u, it is unnecessary- but to those with morality and ethics, it is significant.

@dekohlourised just curious, though, how involved are you in this sector that you can argue facts without much understanding.. it is obvious you just read.. a lot. But you have no understanding on the links between gov and dorm operators and workers. I can remind you tho that cleanliness is INDEED solely workers’ responsibility. Dorm operators do checks and render pest control support if needed but cleanliness is workers’ responsibility and there’s no argument to that. I dont know what you have read and who told you otherwise but yeah.
@deaan but recently I feel their words speak louder than actions leh

@dekohlourised yes, i feel that they have handled the situation well as a governing body. If you have friends working in companies that hire migrant workers, you should ask them if they agree with me. Of course, they could be stricter, but i feel that they have been strict enough and managed the situation in a very humane manner.

text: Which migrant worker dare demand apology sia

answers.text: @zephyrghost dk who youre with/against lol. Anyways,great vocab

@zhen_jiejie social media is a strange thing. On one hand it gives you the freedom (sorta) to air your views but on another hand, throws it back at you on the premise that the views suck. Sigh. #bravenewworld

@tcheeyong91 do you know anything about dorms? employers pay a monthly fee to the dorms for each worker which covers utilities such as cleaning and laundry services, all of which were NOT fulfilled by the operators. if you’re paying for a service and it’s not being provided for you you would surely take issue with it. but because it’s foreign workers it’s their problem right? they work long hours and then when they come back they need to be dorm cleaners, pest busters etc. don’t contribute to an issue you know nothing about.

@nfidaaa you are the companies and hold ultimate responsibilities of the lives of the workers so you should go hold dorm operators responsibility. You are their parent. If your kid is suffering in the kindergaten, you go and settle with the principal. Unless you can't be bothered to.
@zhen_jiejie i agree

@tcheeyong91 to be honest each dorm room is pretty small with double decks and absolutely no beds at all (for fear of bed bugs). They should only have a pillow and at most a blanket, but I doubt they even use a blanket as there’s only fans, so it gets quite stuffy and warm. Apart from their “bed” they only do have a single cabinet to put their clothing and belongings. That’s it. So most of the time the room is kept in decent condition actually. The virus doesn’t discriminate against race, gender, culture or level of hygiene actually. Anyone could get it
@tcheeyong91 🤦‍♂️ I won't feed the troll and try to fill the void of assinine. Everything seems like a verisimilitude anyways.
@nfidaaa yep dorm operators holds most of the responsibilities.

@tcheeyong91 My company has hired construction workers from various countries for over 20 years, so let me share what has been going on. 
In general, ppl on the outside will never understand. they will never know, never see and never experience. unless you deal with fw first hand like us. otherwise you wont know what is happening throughout these years. 
My workers are staying at s11. what we are paying for at s11 is considered MOM approved dormitories.

Prior to this, my workers were housed in private properties, actual landed homes. We rent the whole place for them where max capacity was capped at 8 pax for each private housing, regardless of size. So I can have a 4 storey bungalow but I could only house 8 pax. Subsequently, govt decided to reduce max capacity to 6 pax in 1 location regardless of land size.

then it becomes very ex to pay for such rental because the rental per pax goes up by a significant amount. so we’ve got no choice but to move to purpose-built/ mom approved dorms (which i believe is a move by the govt to make ppl move to purpose built dorms). to be fair, when regulations were less stringent in the past, there were also a lot of stories where workers are cramped into places and its just not sanitary etc. old regulations states 8 ppl in a private property. some ppl idk what they do they house 10, 20, 30 pax god knows. as long as MOM dont come checking or nth major happens like some fire or disease, nobody knows. 
but cuz of these black sheep, our workers suffer. cuz when we rent a place for them, and mom says 8 pax, we only put 8 pax in 1 location. we dont want trouble with MOM so we are very compliant. so moving into a purpose built dorm is a nightmare for our workers.
@yvsarah the virus do discriminate against level of hygiene. You become very dangerous when you spread such false ideology.

@yvsarah oh so you didn't complain to the authorities. So maybe you didn't care as much. As much as dorm operators are at fault, employers are too for not fighting for their workers. If I were you I'd have written into MOM and other agencies multiple times

@_72724 its a dorm not a hotel. They don't have bed-making services. You can still live clean if you tidy your own living space and maintain personal hygiene. Don't comment if your mum has been the one keeping your house clean.

@tcheeyong91 “i’m not trying to be racist” well if you have to write this disclaimer then i have to believe you are one. just admit you think FW are dirty and you’re so damn clean that’s why you’re virus free! :-) not gonna bother discussing this with a racist who is suddenly an expert on all Asian cultures

@tcheeyong91 HAHAH you trying to break into politics is it? So worried about how the governments feelings are hurt in all of this. I’ll tag my previously mentioned friend who can educate your stupid stubborn ass @yvsarah

@zhen_jiejie they don't need to because they know they also played a part in the bad hygienic conditions. Ultimate responsibility to keep the interior of the dorm clean and tidy lies on the person staying in there.

@yvsarah also true that fw dont have a lot of discipline in keeping their own living spaces clean. this is a fact. we as employers needed to run spot checks on their places from time to time and start scolding ppl, but we do it anyway because we care. We care for their surroundings, their living conditions, their health and welfare. Let me bring about the differences in living in private housing vs the purpose-built dorms. What is different is as mentioned above, the dorm operators charge other fees on top of just rental. They made it compulsory for us to pay for laundry. My workers feedback that their clothes are not thoroughly washed, and told us not to waste money on such charges. However we can’t opt out and have to pay anyway. We also do pay conservancy and utilities. These are part of the services that the dorm operators should provide. I wish we knew of their living conditions sooner than later, but the fact is that we are not aware. My own workers have not mentioned anything, probably because their previous dorm has bed bug issues and we have already resolved that by terminating the contract early to move them out, I have no idea. Also we can’t just move in and out of their dorms freely to do checks etc, this is not our duty but duty of the dorm operators. 
It’s not like we set the standards of these dormitories - We have no say. Govt alr pushed many of us to go for purpose-built dorms such as s11, as they reduce the max capacity in private housing for our fw. I can’t say the same for all other companies but I can safely say our company is very nice to our workers. From time to time we buy them food, fruits, beer. we give them clothing. The public likes to talk about employers being mean to our FW, paying for cheap labour etc. On the contrary, we also have morals and empathy. We treat our workers fairly.

oh wow @tcheeyong91 you are a racist prick. Shame on you. Don't say you are not trying to be racist when you conveniently compare our FW to Japanese. Do not talk about things that you do not deal with and do not understand what goes behind the scene. You have no idea how much these employers pay these MOM approved dorm operators for services on top of the rental.

@_72724 well if you argue it like this, it is up to the companies who pay the money to dorm operators to demand the services. How is it entirely the government fault? So the government should hold the hand of the companies and get them to complain to the dorm operators? Money aside, I am talking about maintaining personal hygiene. Even if people do not provide you the service that your company paid for, it does not give you an excuse to be messy and unhygienic. Ya you empathise like all other hypocrites who don't care about FW at all until the time to point fingers.

@tcheeyong91 lol you’re completely missing the point. employers are paying more in charges per employee (excluding rental) TO THE RICH DORM OPERATORS than some small households are paying in monthly conservancy fees. it’s a service that they are forced to pay for and cannot opt out of but the dorm operators are not providing these services that have already been paid for. and thankfully i was raised with more common sense (and empathy) and the ability to do my own chores WITHOUT having to go through NS which was probably your first experience with washing your own crap.
@tcheeyong91 sorry, no matter how clean you are when there are 7-8 person in one small, bad ventilated room you are going to catch it. some other dormitories has more than 8
@_72724 please provide evidence that repeated complain and feedback to MOM were ignored. Otherwise I call bullshit.

@yvsarah ok thanks for sharing. Most people regardless of nationality do not have discipline to keep their living space clean especially when they are living with several other peoples. A collective decision would almost always certainly lead to not giving housekeeping a priority. Your friend mentioned that you complained to MOM about dorm operators not providing housekeeping services. Is this true? Did MOM do anything? They definitely made laundry services compulsory on the simple fact that one out of twelve people can sign up then then other eleven pass their clothing to the one person to wash. That is understandable.

@yvsarah Great insight, glad that you shared and more people should be aware about this. You are paying for a service that is not  fulfilled properly. And I second that fws don’t have a lot of discipline in keeping their own living spaces clean, because my own workers are like tt too. It is indeed a fact.

@tcheeyong91 I don’t think she mentioned I did the complaining. Every dorm operates a little differently I believe (I have crossed reference with other friends in the construction industry) so actually even I don’t understand why they must provide laundry service, and such a poor one at that. My workers haven’t had laundry service in the past and with other dorms and they were definitely capable of washing their own clothes. But I did feedback to the dorm ops about what my workers said regarding the laundry service. They didn’t care, it was either a take it or leave it thing when we signed the tenancy agreement.

@_72724 BMT recruits in Tekong live double deck and in small rooms too. They do not have cleaners in their rooms. They do not have laundry service. They also train long hours. They also use common bathrooms. But I don't see them having virus outbreak. Hmmmm maybe they were made to keep their living quarters clean? Maybe. I don't know. You tell me.

@_72724 yes please educate me with evidence that MOM did nothing at all when your friend complained to them that the dorm operators are intentionally not providing paid housekeeping services. I'd be convinced so please educate me. But that issue aside, all FW can still take charge of their own hygiene regardless. Most people look at photos dipicting messy and dim dorm rooms and immediately point fingers but many do not consider that it is messy because of collective lifestyle choices of these workers. If only there were Japanese FW in Singapore and you could compare between the dorms, I am sure you will be able to find a big difference. I'm not trying to be racist but its more of a cultural thing.

@tcheeyong91 lastly, let me ask you a question. If the Encik never scream at them to clean the area for bunk inspection, you think the area will still be kept clean all the time? Lets be realistic here. There is a driving force behind the clealiness. In the Army, the Officers. Hence, in dormitories the Dorm Operators should be enforcing these standards.

@tcheeyong91 I’m not here to try and stir shit or suddenly act concerned when the issue came to light but there’s a lot of misconceptions. My friend is in the biz and there are lot of restrictions on how they can house their workers leaving them with no choice but to house them in these dorms. And who imposes this if not the governments? The employers are trying to abide by the law and their repeated complains and feedback to the dorm operators and MOM are ignored. And what’s wrong with people showing concern now? It’s not hypocrisy. It could be genuine ignorance and it’s great that more people are away of the plight of FW and the strict guidelines employers are given by MOM. It’s never too late to care.
My family biz has FW as well. They are living a better life by pooling money together to rent a condo. Good life.

@_72724 I believe even the FW are sensible to know that they themselves played a part in them getting the virus and are thankful for getting FREE medical treatment. And then comes along people like you trying to put all the blame on the government. Hello, stop pretending to take the morale highground. If you did not avocate about this FW issue before covid19, you are just as much a culprit.

Flfc
